title: Municipal Dreams
Subtitle: The Rise and Fall of Council Housing
author: John Boughton
notes: A great introduction to a layman like me of the broad sweep of how, housing and economic policies, architecture, design, culture and poltics mix and made concrete (and other materials) in housing. Loved how accessible he made what could easily have been very dry material.

title: Becoming a Supple Leopard
Subtitle: The Ultimate Guide to Resolving Pain,Preventing Injury and Optimizing Atheltic Performance
author: Dr Kelly Starrett
notes: Flicked through and pulled some ideas. Might be good, but haven't drink the kool aid.

title: Empire of Pain
Subtitle: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
author: Patrick Radden Keefe
notes: Listened to this over the course of two weeks, and I loved the way that he kept the focus on the Sacklers, and painstakingly went back through their history to catalogue what awful venal people they are. He took his time to build up a fair picture and even with that they rightly come across as monstrous. I particularly like how the slippery later generations weren't let of the hook despite their wriggling. It does still sting that they all have got off very lightly for the chaos they caused and profited from.

title: A Map of the World
Subtitle: According to Illustrators and Storytellers
author: Antonis Antoniou,Robert Klanten,Sven Ehmann, Hendrick Hellige, Lincoln Dexter
notes: Nice illustrated maps - bit a bit lacking in variety. Was considering buying this - glad I borrowed instead.

title: Kind of Blue
Subtitle: A Political memoir
author: Ken Clarke
notes: His reasoned opinions on the stupidity of the Brexit referendum made me intrigued to read about him. Working class roots and then steady path through government. A bit of a hagiography, but as with many retiring politicians able to say more interesting things when the urge for power fades.

title: Quirkology
Subtitle: The Curious Science of Everyday Lives
author: Richard Wiseman
notes: Women's personal ads would attract more replies if they were written by a man. The opposite is not true of men's ads.People would rather wear a sweater that has been dropped in dog faces and not washed, than one that has been dry-cleaned but used to belong to a mass murderer. Many more nuggets like that in an enjoyable book.

title: Record Play Pause
author: Stephen Morris
notes: Always intersting insight into music making, and a slow reveal about Stephen himself.

title: Inverting the Pyramid
Subtitle: The History of Football Tactics
author: Johnathan Wilson
notes: Detailed, but a bit dry and seemed to run out of steam, once some major innovations had been dealt with. Did make me think that one setup seems to inveitably blend into the next.

title: The Book You Wish Your Parents Had Read (and Your Children Will be Glad That You Did)
author: Phillipa Perry
notes: Engagingly written with things to  try.

title: Managing archives
Subtitle: Foundations, principles and practice
author: Caroline Williams
notes: Work book - plenty to learn - will come back to it.

title: The Thursday Murder Club
author: Richard Osman
notes: Perfect relaxing beach book - which isn't damning with faint praise. Was charming and enjoyable.

title: The Lost Honour of Katharina Blum
author: Heinrich BÃ¶ll
notes: Really nicely written and tight little story.

title: God is not great
author: Christopher Hitchens
notes: Strong start and compelling dismantling of religious thinking. Did ramble a bit, but worthwhile read.

title: The Nowhere Men
author: Michael Calvin
notes: Good on a subculture that is largely unremarked on, yet crucial to a multi billion dollar industry.

title: Arriving Today
Subtitle: From Factory to Front Door -- Why Everything Has Changed About How and What We Buy
author: Christopher Mims
notes: Really enjoyed the bits on the early part of the early supply chain - the containers and boats. The later parts of the chain were a bit depressing - a story of screwing workers to marginal gains - all to feed shareholders.

title: Naked
author: David Sedaris
notes: Funny and witty.

title: The Accidental
author: Ali Smith
notes: Lovely writing - interesting voices.

title: Prisoners of Geography
Subtitle: Ten Maps That Tell You Everything You Need to Know About Global Politics
author: Tim Marshall
notes: Did what lots of books tend to do for me - got me excited enough to bore people with the revelations.

title: Shooting History
Subtitle: A Personal Journey
author: Jon Snow
notes: Bit slow going in parts, but refreshingly honest about his roots, career and a sense of unbelief at his luck.

title: Foundation and Earth
author: Isaac Asimov
notes: Loved the conclusion of the epic.

title: Me talk pretty one day
author: David Sedaris
notes: Resolved to get his after hearing him on Adam Buxton, and delivered in spades.
